tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
"this psalm was written to cause people to remember"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "may God put them to shame and bring disgrace upon them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: let them be turned back and brought to dishonor
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "may God turn them around and make them ashamed for what they have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
To be stopped or thwarted is spoken of as being turned back from their attack. AT: "stopped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is an expression of mocking laughter. You may replace "Aha, aha" with whatever laughing sounds like in your language. AT: "those who mock and laugh at me"
Seeking God represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. AT: "ask you for help" or "think about you and obey you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of gladness. AT: "rejoice greatly" or "be very glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as an action. AT: "love you because you saved them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is an exaggeration in order to emphasize the importance of praising God often. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Let everyone praise God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the words "poor" and "needy" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he is unable to help himself. AT: "very needy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The writer speaks of God as if he is running to the writer in order to help him. AT: "come quickly to help me!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you are my help and you rescue me
tn.text: Here the phrase "you rescue me" explains how God is his "help." AT: "you help me by rescuing me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "please come quickly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
